My understanding of the power of annotation is that you can put all the
information related to a class in the same file:
- configuration management
- persistence
- tests
- etc.

This is just like pushing the limit of encapsulation to a higher level.

If you make a change in the class, you can easily change accordingly all
related information through annotations.

However, not all that information is to be provided with the code.

So one can have a set tools that clean up the code (preprocessing
annotations) before releasing it.

I just played a bit with apt and the annotation API: it does not look
that complicated to do a preprocessor removing from the code all methods
annotated by junit annotations.

Daniel
